title: Dogmersfield Park Walking Route

images.title: Andrew Smith / Tundry Pond
images.caption: Tundry Pond. A large pond in Dogmersfield Park. Up ahead you can see the more northerly of two bridges on either side of an island.

images.title: Hugh Craddock / Bridge on Tundry Pond
images.caption: Bridge on Tundry Pond. The bridge carries the north carriage drive to Dogmersfield Park across Tundry Pond. As is common with carriage drives, this one is no longer in regular use by vehicles, but remains as an ornamental feature.

images.title: Andrew Mathewson / Dogmersfield Park
images.caption: Dogmersfield Park house. The house dates from the 1920s, and was formerly the dower house to the park. The house is set in extensive parkland.

images.title: Canalside Life by Dogmersfield by Colin Smith, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Canalside Life by Dogmersfield

images.title: Village Green, Dogmersfield by Colin Smith, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Village Green, Dogmersfield

images.title: Picturesque Dogmersfield by Colin Smith, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Picturesque Dogmersfield. A pretty cottage in the small village which lies just to the north east of the park.

images.title: John Thorn / Dogmersfield Park Church
images.caption: Dogmersfield Park Church. Former parish church of All Saints seen from the southwest. Now a private house.

images.title: Sandy Hill Bridge, Basingstoke Canal by don cload, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sandy Hill Bridge, Basingstoke Canal. On the western side of the park.

description: Enjoy an easy stroll through Dogmersfield park on this circular walk in Hampshire. The walk starts at the Basingstoke Canal car park in Odiham and follows the canal towpath past Odiham Common to the pretty Tundry Pond. You then follow footpaths around Dogmersfield Lake before picking up the canal to take you back to the car park. The park is located just to the west of Fleet and Farnborough. The Odiham Castle and Canal Walk starts from the same car park. You can follow the canal a couple of miles to the west to visit the historic ruins of the 13th century castle. There are also views of the River Whitewater at Warnborough Green to enjoy here.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Queen's Head dates from the 17th Century and includes many of the original features. The pub commemorates the visit of Catherine of Aragon, who would later become Henry VIII’s first wife. Outside there is a lovely large garden area to sit in on warmer days. You can find them in the village on Pilcot Lane with postcode RG27 8SY for your sat navs. They have a car park and are also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The Crondall Walk visits the park from the nearby settlement. The village includes a noteworthy Norman church and a fine 500 year old pub. The Three Castles Path passes through the park. This historically themed long distance trail will take you from Windsor Castle to Winchester Castle, visiting the ruined Odiham Castle on the way. For more walking ideas in the area see the Hampshire Walks page.

display_address: Basingstoke Canal Towpath, Odiham, Hart, Hampshire, England, RG29 1AL, United Kingdom
